taskDescription:
We all love chess, right? Diving into possible strategies to become a master in chess, we found these opening principles: 

 

Chess opening principles:

 

   - Develop your pieces.

   - Don't make too many pawn moves.

   - Don't bring your queen out too early.

   - Don't move the same piece twice.

   - Castle early.

   - Develop towards the centre.

   - Clear the back rank and connect your rooks.

 

As you can see, these are written as “tips” that follow a common style and use chess vocabulary (pawn, queen, rooks, castle). Let’s see what generic MT is able to do with them.

Take these sentences and paste them all together in a couple of available MT systems of your choice. Take a look to how the system: 

  • respects and maintains the tip-like style of the whole bunch of sentences

  • is able to provide the appropriate translation for “queen”, “Castle early” or “Clear the back rank”

We provide here the translation into Spanish by different systems: 

MT1: 

Principios de las aperturas de ajedrez:

   - Desarrolle sus piezas.

   - No haga demasiados movimientos de peones.

   - No saque su reina demasiado pronto.

   - No mueva la misma pieza dos veces.

   - Encastra pronto.

   - Desarrolla hacia el centro.

   - Despeja la última fila y conecta tus torres.

In this case, there is a style change from formal/informal treatment from tip 5 to tip 6. Translation for “Queen” is “reina” that would be immediately corrected by any chess player for “Dama”, “Castle early”, even if trying with a verb, is wrong as the right in-domain verb is “Enrocar” (see how curious, in Spanish we say “en-roc-ar” a word with very similar root to the English word “rook” although the translation of “rook” is “torre”, nothing to do!” and finally, “Clear the back rank” gets a decent translation this time. We are not paying attention to the first sentence, but the plural in “aperturas” is not the best translation ever. 

MT2: 

Principios de apertura del ajedrez:

    - Desarrolla tus piezas.

    - No hagas demasiados movimientos de peón.

    - No saques a tu reina demasiado pronto.

    - No muevas la misma pieza dos veces.

    - Castillo temprano.

    - Desarrollar hacia el centro.

    - Completa la última fila y conecta tus torres.

Again, there is a mix of styles in the way the tips are translated, “dama” if preferred to “reina” in Spanish, “Castle early” is translated as a “noun + adverb” and not as a “verb + adverb” getting it completely wrong and “Clear the back rank” gets a very odd translation as if it was “Complete/Fill in the back rank”.

MT3:

Principios de apertura del ajedrez:

- Desarrolla tus piezas.

   - No hagas demasiados movimientos de peones.

   - No saques a tu reina demasiado pronto.

   - No muevas la misma pieza dos veces.

   - Castillo temprano.

   - Desarrollarse hacia el centro.

   - Despeje el rango trasero y conecte sus torres.

Very similar set of errors: mix of styles, “reina” instead of “dama”, “Castle early” not translated as a “verb + adverb” but as a “noun + adverb” and although the verb for “Clear the back rank” is OK, the rest “rango trasero” is completely wrong. 
 

Did you have a similar experience in the translations you got?

For the provided examples, we used generic MT systems. Could we assume that assembling a corpus about chess would solve all of these problems?
